question.title: How to prove that Java doesn't support Multiple Inheritance?

node.contents: Prove? There is a language specification. Multiple inheritance is not in there.

astNode.text: Prove? There is a language specification. Multiple inheritance is not in there.

node.contents: Try compiling `public class Child extends Parent1, Parent2 {...`

astNode.text: Try compiling `public class Child extends Parent1, Parent2 {...`

node.contents: No proof is required of statements in the JLS. You just cite them.

astNode.text: No proof is required of statements in the JLS. You just cite them.

node.contents: [JLS 8.1.4](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.1.4) describes the structure of super class declaration. Note, that a class can implement several interfaces. For that, see [JLS 8.1.5](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.1.5). (I looked it up in the JLS of Java 8.)

astNode.text: [JLS 8.1.4](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.1.4) describes the structure of super class declaration. Note, that a class can implement several interfaces. For that, see [JLS 8.1.5](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se8/html/jls-8.html#jls-8.1.5). (I looked it up in the JLS of Java 8.)

node.contents: If you learned a lot of theory in your class, covering how to prove absence or existence of features, you should take a look at the exact definition your prof used for "Multiple Inheritance" (note that allowing multiple interfaces can be interpreted as Multiple Inheritance, according to some definitions), and then try a proof by contradiction and construction (you construct something that uses multiple inheritance in its most general form but contradicts with the specs).

astNode.text: If you learned a lot of theory in your class, covering how to prove absence or existence of features, you should take a look at the exact definition your prof used for "Multiple Inheritance" (note that allowing multiple interfaces can be interpreted as Multiple Inheritance, according to some definitions), and then try a proof by contradiction and construction (you construct something that uses multiple inheritance in its most general form but contradicts with the specs).

node.contents: You should also note that proof by compilation isn't valid, as it doesn't exclude the possibility of compiler bugs, however remote.

astNode.text: You should also note that proof by compilation isn't valid, as it doesn't exclude the possibility of compiler bugs, however remote.

node.contents: How can we prove that java doesn't support multiple inheritance?

astNode.text: How can we prove that java doesn't support multiple inheritance?

node.contents: Is there any alternative method to implement Multiple Inheritance in Java?

astNode.text: Is there any alternative method to implement Multiple Inheritance in Java?

node.contents: No, you don't. Interface provides only a subset of true multiple inheritance properties. It's wrong and misleading to consider these two terms as interchangeable.

astNode.text: No, you don't. Interface provides only a subset of true multiple inheritance properties. It's wrong and misleading to consider these two terms as interchangeable.

node.contents: Java does not support multiple inheritance but in Java you can achieve multiple inheritance using less complex feature called - Interfaces.

astNode.text: Java does not support multiple inheritance but in Java you can achieve multiple inheritance using less complex feature called - Interfaces.

node.contents: Is there any alternative method to implement Multiple Inheritance in Java

node.contents:
• implementing multiple interfaces

  • using object composition and delegating method calls to the objects that implement the pieces you would otherwise have inherited

• implementing multiple interfaces

node.contents: You fixed the form, but not the content.

elements.contents: class A { public void methodAClassA() { System.out.println("In ClassA MethodA"); } } class B extends A{ public void methodAClassA(){ System.out.print("in Class B Method ClassA"); } } class C extends A,B {}

units.rawText: class A { public void methodAClassA() { System.out.println("In ClassA MethodA"); } } class B extends A{ public void methodAClassA(){ System.out.print("in Class B Method ClassA"); } } class C extends A,B {}

node.contents: There is no multiple inheritance in java as it is specified by the language specification.

node.contents:
Multiple Inheritance

There is no multiple inheritance in java. Correct, except we can cast every type to every another one, if we want.

Multiple Inheritance

node.contents: I really do not recommend this. It is considered a "best practice" to implement multiple interfaces if you want something which resembles multiple inheritance or as others pointed out you can use composition and delegation as well.

astNode.text: I really do not recommend this. It is considered a "best practice" to implement multiple interfaces if you want something which resembles multiple inheritance or as others pointed out you can use composition and delegation as well.

node.contents: If an one class directly inherited from two or more classes it will be multiple inheritances. But in java this is not allowed.

astNode.text: If an one class directly inherited from two or more classes it will be multiple inheritances. But in java this is not allowed.

node.contents: We don’t need a proof as it is specified in java language specification.

node.contents: However If you need a proof try to compile below(This will not compile)

astNode.text: However If you need a proof try to compile below(This will not compile)

elements.contents: class A{ void doSomething(){ System.out.println(“from class A”); } } class B{ void doSomething(){ System.out.println(“from class B”); } } class C extends A,B{ public static void main(String arr[]){ C cob= new C(); cob.doSomething();//now how does compiler knows which super method to call? } }

comments.text: //now how does compiler knows which super method to call? } }
//now how does compiler knows which super method to call? } }

node.contents: The reason that Java's creators chose not to allow multiple inheritance is that it can become quite messy. But indeed you can have something like this.

astNode.text: The reason that Java's creators chose not to allow multiple inheritance is that it can become quite messy. But indeed you can have something like this.

elements.contents: public interface InterfaceA { public void doSomething(); } public interface InterfaceB { public void doSomething(); } public interface InterfaceC extends InterfaceA, InterfaceB { //same method is declared in InterfaceA and InterfaceB both public void doSomething(); }

comments.text: //same method is declared in InterfaceA and InterfaceB both public void doSomething(); }
